I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
programmatic approach for the Promoting Innovative Financial Inclusion Program and (ii) a policy-
based loan to the Republic of Indonesia for subprogram 1 of the Promoting Innovative Financial 
Inclusion Program. 
 
2.  The programmatic approach supports the government’s ongoing efforts to further enhance 
financial inclusion. It will (i) improve the government’s capabilities to better target and track 
financial inclusion efforts and enhance supporting infrastructure; (ii) directly increase access to 
finance for micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) and underserved segments 
using innovative technology; and (iii) strengthen the regulatory framework for digital financial 
services, data privacy, and consumer protection. More equitable and efficient access to financial 
products and services will also help mitigate the adverse impacts of the coronavirus disease 
(COVID-19) pandemic, foster recovery and the rebuilding of livelihoods, and prepare for future 
economic shocks. Financial inclusion therefore will play an important role in the government’s 
National Economic Recovery (PEN) program in response to COVID-19. The program aligns with 
the  government’s  National  Medium-Term  Development  Plan,  2020–2024  and  the  second 
strategic pathway of the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) country partnership strategy for 
Indonesia, 2020–2024.1 It contributes to the ADB Strategy 2030 priorities of addressing remaining 
poverty and reducing inequalities (operational priority 1), accelerating progress in gender equality 
(operational priority 2), and tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and 
enhancing environmental sustainability (operational priority 3).2 
 
II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
3.  Background. The Indonesian economy has grown by an annual average of 5.0% from 
2000 to 2019, and made impressive progress in poverty reduction. The number of people living 
below the national poverty line declined by more than half, from 23.4% in 1999 to 9.2% in 2019.3 
However, the country did not meet its targeted poverty rate of 7%–8% under the National Medium-
Term Development Plan, 2015–2019. A sizable portion of the population clusters only marginally 
above the national poverty line, and about one-fifth of the population remains poor or near poor 
and is highly vulnerable to shocks, including climate shocks.4 The severity of poverty varies widely 
across this highly diverse country, as does the quality of infrastructure and the availability of 
services. The Gini coefficient improved from 0.41 in 2014 to 0.38 in 2019, but Indonesia remains 
one of the most unequal countries in Southeast Asia (footnote 3). While inequality is prevalent in 
urban areas, poverty rates are higher in rural and remote areas. Eastern Indonesia has very high 
rates of rural poverty, with development having bypassed many indigenous communities. Women 
are often marginalized and suffer higher rates of poverty and inequality. 
 
4.  Reducing poverty and inequality has become even more challenging because of the global 
economic recession induced by the COVID-19 pandemic. The economy is projected to contract 
in 2020 by 1%, Indonesia’s worst performance in 21 years, and downside risk to the forecast is

significant because of serious disruption to economic activity.5 MSMEs have been hit hard with 
nearly  one  in  five  women-led  businesses  closed.6 Labor  market  deterioration  will  be  felt 
disproportionately by the most vulnerable, including the 57% of workers who are only informally 
employed.7 Poverty incidence is expected to increase to 11.9%–12.8% in 2020, reversing recent 
gains.  As  the  COVID-19  pandemic  takes  away  jobs  and  worsens  poverty,  it  complicates 
addressing barriers to financial inclusion. Focusing on financially excluded segments of the 
population is particularly urgent since they are the least likely to have high-quality, affordable 
health care and adequate savings or access to credit to help them weather an economic downturn. 
In addition, their informal livelihoods are particularly vulnerable to interruption under COVID-19. 
 
5.  To address the challenge of poverty and inequality—and in response to the COVID-19 
pandemic—the government is pursuing a comprehensive program with a strong focus on financial 
inclusion.8 In  this  regard,  internationally  comparable  Global  Findex  data  show  Indonesia 
advancing more quickly than its peers in East Asia and the Pacific (Figure 1).9 The Global Findex 
survey reports the percentage of adults in Indonesia with a bank account rising markedly from 
20% in 2011 to 36% in 2014 and 49% in 2017. The recent Financial Inclusion Insights Survey by 
the Indonesian National Council for Financial Inclusion (Dewan Nasional Keuangan Inklusif or 
DNKI) shows a similar trend, with 56% of adults holding an account in 2018.10 However, by this 
measure of financial inclusion, Indonesia still lagged Malaysia at 85% and Thailand at 82% in 
2017.

6.  Access to a transaction account is the first step toward broader financial inclusion. In fact, 
recent progress in financial inclusion can be attributed to the development of “government to 
person” payments including social transfers, which increased the number of basic savings

6  ACCION. 2020. COVID-19 and MSMEs: Data and Analysis to Understand Impact. 
7  Statistics Indonesia. 2020. Labor Force Situation in Indonesia: February 2020. Jakarta. 
8  Financial inclusion is broadly defined as individuals and businesses having access to useful and affordable financial 
products and services that meet their needs and are delivered in a responsible and sustainable manner. 
9  World Bank. 2018. The Global Findex Database 2017. Washington, DC.

3 
accounts held by low-income people. However, the number of Indonesians excluded from the 
formal financial system remains significant at 51% (footnote 9). The degree of exclusion varies 
significantly  across  regions  and  by  gender  and  other  social  factors.  Moreover,  despite 
improvement, many people remain poorly served by the formal finance sector, their financial 
access falling short of financial depth. 
 
7.  Development constraints. Providing financial services to all is a unique challenge in a 
country as geographically dispersed and socio-culturally diverse as Indonesia. For financial 
inclusion to be meaningful, holders of bank accounts must use them effectively and cultivate 
banking habits to improve their lives. Moreover, they should have access to an array of high-
quality and affordable financial products and services to meet their evolving needs. To address 
the dual challenges of poverty and inequality toward achieving sustainable development over the 
long term, more must be done to make financial products and services more accessible and truly 
usable for populations heretofore excluded from the formal financial system. Government efforts 
to this end are hampered by (i) inadequate data and supporting infrastructure, (ii) limited access 
to finance for MSMEs and other underserved segments, and (iii) low financial literacy and 
inadequate consumer protection. 
 
8.  Inadequate data and supporting infrastructure. Comprehensive data—consistent, up-
to-date, and disaggregated—are critical to designing and implementing a cohesive and well-
coordinated approach to financial inclusion. Existing datasets are often inconsistent and fall back 
on account ownership as a proxy for financial inclusion. Existing data cloak other dimensions of 
financial inclusion as well, such as disparate market segments. More in-depth examination is 
needed of both demand for and the supply of financial products and services for MSMEs and 
underserved individuals and households. Greater focus is needed on disaggregating data by sex 
and analysis of regional disparities. In addition, proper reporting, monitoring, and evaluation 
mechanisms are critical to assessing the outcomes of the government’s financial inclusion 
programs. Supporting infrastructure is unable to facilitate full integration of the unbanked and 
underbanked into the formal financial system. While real-time payment infrastructure is in place, 
the existing system does not allow micro payment processing involving very small sum of money, 
which challenges its usefulness for driving digital financial inclusion. The number of branchless 
banking agents has expanded but opening a bank account through a branchless banking agent 
may take more than 5 days because account-opening forms still need to be physically transported. 
Consequently, only a few financial service providers prioritize customer acquisition through their 
field agents. The national biometric identification project has registered and collected biometric 
data on more than 100 million Indonesians, yet the database can be accessed by only a limited 
number of market participants for only a few uses. This precludes using biometric data to enable 
digital and remote personal identity verification with sufficient certainty to satisfy stringent know-
your-customer requirements. Further, this prevents a link between biometric identification and 
electronic know your customer (e-KYC), which could facilitate speedier account opening and 
electronic payments.  
 
9.  Insufficient  focused  efforts  to  support  smaller  enterprises  and  underserved 
segments. In 2018, Indonesia’s 64 million MSMEs accounted for a large portion of all businesses 
and employed most of the workforce. Women ran nearly half of them.11 Lack of access to finance 
is a key challenge for MSMEs, as fewer than a quarter of them can get a loan to start and grow a 
business. As a result, most are micro enterprises that struggle to grow to small or medium-sized 
status. The finance sector in Indonesia is dominated by intermediated lending disbursed by 
traditional banks and remains less efficient than its regional peers. Credit information and risk 
 
11 Statistics Indonesia. 2019. Potential for Increasing Performance Micro and Small Enterprises. Jakarta.

4 
management systems are underdeveloped, and technology has not been fully exploited to reach 
MSMEs. Proactive and focused efforts are needed to improve institutional credit delivery in an 
integrated,  timely,  and  efficient  manner  through  technology-driven  solutions.  In  addition, 
significant regional disparities remain in access to a range of financial products for savings, credit, 
remittance, payment, investment, and insurance. Similar disparities persist between population 
groups, with women, youth, and rural communities particularly at risk of being left behind. 
According to Global Findex, in 2017, only 18.4% of adult population borrowed from a financial 
institution or used a credit card. For women, the rate was 18.0% and for youth 8.0%,12  though 
youth are half of the population. Closing these remaining gaps in financial access, including the 
gender gap, is a major priority in line with the National Medium-Term Development Plan, 2020–
2024. 
 
10.  Need for enhanced financial literacy, consumer protection, and financial technology 
supervision. The emerging financial technology (fintech) industry has fostered innovations and 
opportunities that complement the role of banks and capital market intermediaries, but it has also 
made financial products and services more complex and heightened risks to consumers and the 
finance  sector.  Many  consumers,  especially  women,  lack  financial  experience  and  the 
competence that comes with it. A survey in 2019 found the financial literacy rate in Indonesia to 
be  only  38.03%.13 Fintech  industry  expansion  and  a  corresponding  increase  in  consumer 
complaints of abusive practices in digital financial services indicate a need for consumers to 
acquire greater digital financial literacy and for the enactment of an industry code of conduct to 
which all registered and licensed fintech companies must adhere.14 Consumer complaint and 
redress mechanisms need to be enhanced further and awareness of them raised among women. 
Indonesia has six dispute-resolution institutions, one each for banking, capital markets, insurance, 
multifinance, guarantees, and pension funds. However, no institution covers microfinance, and 
emerging financial products do not fit neatly into any one sector, which gives rise to the need for 
a unified independent dispute-resolution mechanism that covers the entire finance sector. Finally, 
financial regulators need to improve the required systems and strengthen their capacity for market 
conduct  monitoring  and  supervision.  As  regulators  try  to  both  facilitate  and  shape  the 
development of a dynamic fintech industry, new oversight tools such as regulatory technology 
(regtech) and supervisory technology (suptech) are needed to enable and enhance supervision 
and regulation while making it more cost-effective and data-intensive. 
 
11.  ADB engagement and development partner coordination. ADB has supported finance 
sector development in Indonesia since 2002. Its engagement in financial inclusion in Indonesia 
began  with  support  for  developing  microfinance  to  expand  access  for  MSMEs  under  the 
Earthquake and Tsunami Emergency Support Project in 2005.15 Since then, ADB has supported 
the government’s financial inclusion agenda through various programs and technical assistance 
(TAs). It has coordinated initiatives in the area of financial inclusion with German Development 
Cooperation through KfW, the United Nations Capital Development Fund, the Bill & Melinda Gates 
Foundation, the World Bank, the Islamic Development Bank, Women’s World Banking, and the 
International Labour Organization, as well as with the International Monetary Fund on policy 
dialogue, fiscal projections, and macroeconomic analysis.

12.  Lessons. Most recently, ADB supported the government and the Financial Services 
Authority (Otoritas Jasa Keuangan or OJK)16 under the Financial Market Development and 
Inclusion Program17 and TA for Promoting Innovative Financial Inclusion18 to enhance access to 
finance through innovative approaches, financial literacy, and consumer protection. ADB support 
helped the government establish the DNKI, promulgate digital finance regulations, and expand 
branchless banking, laying the foundation for the program. Its long-term engagement in the 
finance sector informed program design through four key lessons: (i) in the finance sector, 
dedicated programs should focus on one subsector at a time for better impact; (ii) financial stability 
and capital market development need to be complemented with reform to improve financial 
access for underserved segments and thereby maximize the economic impact of development; 
(iii) reform to enhance financial inclusion should be holistic, requiring complementary measures 
in financial literacy, consumer protection, and fintech; and (iv) an overarching framework for 
fintech is required to ensure both sector development and consumer protection.19 
 
B.  Policy Reform and ADB’s Value Addition 
 
13.  Government  reform  program.  The  National  Medium-Term  Development  Plan, 
2020–2024 reinforces financial inclusion as a priority that includes increasing MSME access to 
 
credit. Presidential Regulation No. 82 of 2016 on the National Strategy for Financial Inclusion set 
priorities and approaches to expand financial inclusion during 2016–2019 in the form of five pillars: 
(i)  financial  education,  (ii)  public  property  rights,  (iii)  intermediation  facility  and  distribution 
channels, (iv) financial services in the government sector, and (v) consumer protection.20 These 
pillars  are  supported  by  three  enablers  of  conducive  policies  and  regulations,  supporting  
(i) infrastructure, (ii) information technology, and (iii) effective organization and implementation 
mechanisms. Key achievements under the strategy included tripling the number of e-money and 
branchless  banking  agents  and  introducing  such  initiatives  as  cashless  social  assistance 
programs. The DNKI coordinates implementation and monitoring of all financial inclusion efforts 
and is chaired by the President of Indonesia and led by the Coordinating Ministry of Economic 
Affairs in collaboration with 13 implementing agencies. 
 
16 The OJK regulates and supervises financial services. It was established in 2012 as a unified authority to regulate the 
capital market, banking, and nonbank financial institutions under Act No. 21 of 2011, supported by ADB. The OJK 
replaced the Capital Market and Financial Institutions Supervisory Agency and assumed the responsibility of Bank 
Indonesia for bank supervision. 
17 ADB. 2019. Republic of Indonesia: Financial Market Development and Inclusion Program. Manila. 
18 ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Indonesia for Promoting Innovative Financial Inclusion. Manila. 
19 ADB. Forthcoming. Completion Report: Financial Market Development and Inclusion Program in Indonesia. Manila. 
20 Government of Indonesia. 2016. National Strategy for Financial Inclusion. Jakarta.

6 
14.  Proposed policy reforms. The program comprises two subprograms designed to deepen 
ADB’s engagement and continue its support under the Financial Market Development and 
Inclusion Program, through which ADB became engaged in financial inclusion (footnote 17). The 
program supports new tech-enabled opportunities to accelerate and enhance financial inclusion, 
especially under the COVID-19 pandemic. A programmatic approach is selected as it provides 
continuing engagement to support complex reform with flexibility to accommodate stakeholder 
feedback.  The  program  supports  ongoing  government  efforts  toward  financial  inclusion  by 
focusing on three key reform areas: (i) tools and infrastructure for financial inclusion, (ii) access 
to finance for MSMEs and marginalized groups including women and youth, and (iii) supervision 
and consumer protection measures for responsible financial inclusion. Fintech is a crosscutting 
area. Financial inclusion reform will boost government efforts to mitigate COVID-19 impacts by 
leveraging technology to foster financial innovation and strengthening consumer protection. A 
third  subprogram  may  be  considered,  depending  on  demand  from  the  government  and 
achievements under subprograms 1 and 2. 
 
15.  Tools and infrastructure for financial inclusion. This reform area supports evidence-
based policies to promote a cohesive and coordinated approach to financial inclusion and improve 
supporting infrastructure. There are six key accomplishments under subprogram 1. First, the 
government  completed  comprehensive  national  and  regional  data  collection  exercises  with 
particular focus on women and youth, and issued the new National Strategy for Financial Inclusion, 
2020–2024. The regulation provided the legal basis to set financial inclusion targets to promote 
deepening of financial services. The ministries of women’s empowerment and of youth were 
added as new members of the DNKI. Second, the government launched a financial access map 
to further identify the needs of financially underserved people including women; improve the 
design, implementation, and monitoring of financial inclusion strategies and action plans; and 
enable better targeting of future initiatives based on their needs. Third, the government launched 
Indonesia’s Payment System Blueprint 2025 to reinforce the integration of the national digital 
economy  and  finance.  The  existing  policy  to  increase  the  use  of  digital  transactions  was 
strengthened to enhance transaction efficiency toward providing a more inclusive payment 
ecosystem. Fourth, the government pilot tested the use of national biometric identification to 
facilitate e-KYC requirements, make it easier to open a bank account, and enhance the delivery 
of digital financial services to the unbanked and underbanked. Fifth, the OJK developed a 5-year 
digital finance innovation road map and action plan to encourage greater use of technology. Sixth, 
within this framework, an innovative geospatial financial service mobile application was launched 
to allow the unbanked and underbanked to locate branchless banking agents and other financial 
service providers in real time. Under subprogram 2, the government will expand the financial 
access map and launch a complementary sex-disaggregated financial inclusion and literacy data 
dashboard. Using the data collected under subprogram 1, the government will adopt a time-bound 
financial inclusion action plan for 2020–2024 with gender targets to deepen women’s financial 
inclusion. The government will also promote the greater use of fintech, fully automate the know-
your-customer process, and require financial service providers to register on the geospatial 
financial service mobile application. 
 
16.  Access  to  finance  for  smaller  enterprises  and  marginalized  groups  including 
women and youth. This reform area provides greater access to finance for MSMEs, which 
complements  government  efforts  to  support  MSMEs  affected  by  COVID-19,  and  other 
marginalized segments, in particular women and youth.21 Under subprogram 1, the government

interest for MSME credit. In March 2020, the OJK issued a regulation that relaxed requirements to enable banks to

7 
accomplished  five  key  reforms.  First,  the  OJK  adopted  measures  to  reduce  information 
asymmetry and allow prospective lenders to better assess credit risk posed by MSMEs. For 
example, the OJK adopted a regulatory framework to regulate alternative credit scoring used by 
fintech entities, enabling a comprehensive credit scoring mechanism and making credit access 
possible for the unbanked and underbanked, notably women. Second, the OJK established the 
Eastern  Indonesia  Financial  Innovation  Lab  (EIFIL)  for  regional  development  banks.  In 
partnership with the fintech industry, this initiative will identify and deploy more innovative 
technology solutions that extend MSME access to credit, especially in rural areas. The EIFIL will 
initially introduce an innovation accelerator program for regional development banks in Nusa 
Tenggara Barat, Nusa Tenggara Timur, North Sulawesi, and Maluku focusing on agriculture and 
tourism MSMEs owned by women and youth and affected by COVID-19. Third, the OJK, 
supported by the Ministry of Home Affairs, adopted a strategic road map and expanded the Team 
for Acceleration of Regional Financial Access to address regional disparities. Fourth, recognizing 
the need for proactive measures to address gender gaps, the government launched the world’s 
first standalone financial inclusion strategy for women. This strategy includes a time-bound action 
plan with targets, the first national definition of businesses owned and/or led by women, and a 
women’s financial inclusion network at the level of the DNKI. Fifth, similarly, to enhance financial 
services for youth, the OJK launched a dedicated financial inclusion strategy and rolled out an 
innovative  program  of  youth  financial  inclusion  ambassadors  to  function  as  influencers  on 
universities and over social media toward enhancing financial awareness. Under subprogram 2, 
the government will issue regulations to adopt alternative credit scoring to further mitigate risk 
posed by lending to MSMEs. The OJK will expand the EIFIL and, in partnership with the fintech 
industry, provide further support to MSMEs. The government will implement dedicated financial 
inclusion plans covering small businesses owned by women and youth, backed by specific 
strategies developed through data analysis conducted under the first reform area. 
 
17.  Supervision and consumer protection measures for responsible financial inclusion. 
This reform area strengthens finance sector governance, consumer protection, and financial 
literacy in response to the rising use of fintech and an expected increase in insolvency and over-
indebtedness during the COVID-19 crisis. Subprogram 1 had four key accomplishments. First, 
the government created a strategic framework for adopting regtech and suptech. This will anchor 
efforts to accelerate data-intensive risk assessment and enable supervisory, regulatory, and 
policy decision-making facilitated by artificial intelligence, machine learning, natural language 
processing, and data analytics. Second, the government enhanced regulation of the fintech 
industry by appointing the Indonesia Fintech Association (Asosiasi Fintech Indonesia or AFTECH) 
as a self-regulatory organization. AFTECH will complement OJK efforts to supervise market 
conduct and protect digital financial consumers. Third, to enhance consumer protection, the 
government established a coordinated effort to merge the separate dispute-resolution centers. 
Fourth, the government pilot tested an innovative financial education and career exploration 
program  for  Indonesian  youth  called  Y-Bank,  supported  by  more  than  20  domestic  and 
international financial institutions. The Y-Bank curriculum is designed to be gender sensitive and 
encourage more female participation. Under subprogram 2, the OJK will adopt comprehensive 
regtech and suptech frameworks. In addition, AFTECH, with OJK’s authorization, will issue a code 
of ethics and conduct for the fintech industry. Six separate dispute-resolution institutions will be 
consolidated into a unified body to provide access to more effective financial dispute resolutions. 
Finally, the government will implement international security and privacy standards for financial 
institutions and fintech entities and support the further expansion of the Y-Bank program.

C.  Impacts of the Reform 
18.  The program’s impact aligns with the aim under the National Medium-Term Development 
Plan, 2020–2024 for Indonesia to become an upper-middle-income country that is prosperous, 
fair, and sustainable by 2024 (footnote 1). The program outcome will be the promotion of a more 
inclusive financial service sector.22 Subprogram 1 supports the government’s ongoing financial 
inclusion agenda by better targeting financially underserved people and introducing the policy and 
technology necessary to enable better access to formal financial products and services, improve 
their quality, and increase their use. Subprogram 2 will implement and expand reforms introduced 
under subprogram 1. Access to a bank account enables the use of additional financial services, 
and credit opens up economic opportunity. Financial literacy has lasting benefits on behavior and 
is likely to become self-reinforcing with more experience. Regulatory reform will promote more 
competition among financial service providers, which should improve product features and lower 
prices paid by MSMEs and underserved people. Increased financial inclusion will therefore 
improve productivity and efficiency and narrow income inequality.23  
 
D.  Development Financing Needs and Budget Support 
19.  The government has requested a loan of $500 million from ADB ordinary capital resources 
to help finance subprogram 1. The loan will have a 15-year term including a grace period of 3 
years, an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate 
(LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year, and such other terms 
and conditions as set forth in the draft loan agreement. Using the straight-line repayment method, 
the average maturity is 9.25 years, and no maturity premium is payable to ADB. The indicative 
loan amount for subprogram 2 is also $500 million. German development cooperation through 
KfW is cofinancing subprogram 1 with €200 million equivalent. The government’s projected total 
gross borrowing requirement for 2020 has increased from $42.4 billion to $107.0 billion because 
of  COVID-19  impacts.  To  finance  this  need,  the  government  plans  to  raise  $82.4  billion 
domestically through debt issuance in rupiah (increased from $32.9 billion prior to COVID-19), 
$16.5 billion through debt issuance in foreign currencies, $0.2 billion through domestic loans, and 
$7.9 billion through official development assistance.24 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The Ministry of Finance will be the executing agency. The OJK, the Coordinating Ministry 
of Economic Affairs, and Bank Indonesia will be the implementing agencies. Implementation 
would be from May 2019 to December 2020 for subprogram 1 and January 2021 to December 
2022 for subprogram 2. The proceeds of the policy-based loan will be withdrawn in accordance 
with the ADB Loan Disbursement Handbook (2017, as amended from time to time). 
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
21.  Safeguards. In compliance with the ADB Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the program 
is category C for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. It is expected to 
have no environmental or social impacts as defined in the ADB Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009).

22.  Poverty and social. COVID-19 pandemic disruption of employment and livelihoods is 
placing particularly heavy burdens on the most vulnerable in society and worsening poverty. An 
estimated 5.2 million Indonesians could lose their jobs, and nearly 10.0 million will be pushed into 
poverty in 2020. As those falling into poverty are the households most excluded by the formal 
financial  system,  their  financial  inclusion  can  help  defend  them  from  future  poverty  and 
vulnerability. Reform under the program covers digital finance innovation, payment systems, e-
KYC, alternative credit scoring, regional financial access, and alternate dispute resolution, which 
will facilitate and accelerate the responsible provision of financial services to heretofore excluded 
people, creating opportunity and reducing poverty. 
 
23.  Gender. Subprogram 1 is categorized as gender equity as a theme with proactive actions 
and targets designed to strengthen and promote women’s economic resilience and empowerment 
by tackling key gender challenges. Despite Indonesia being one of the few countries with a 
reverse gender gap in bank account ownership, persistent gender gaps remain in access to and 
use of many financial services. For example, while the bank account ownership rate is 51% for 
women and 46% for men, men are 6% more likely to have an active account. Further, a sizeable 
gap in labor force participation sees only 51% of women employed as opposed to 83% of men. 
Businesses owned or led by women tend to be very small and struggle to survive and grow 
because their access to markets and networks is relatively limited. COVID-19 has deepened 
these challenges because women’s jobs and businesses are concentrated in industries hard hit 
by the pandemic, such as tourism, and women now have more unpaid care and domestic work, 
limiting the time available for paid work. Subprogram 1 will provide a comprehensive response to 
gender-specific challenges to financial inclusion by (i) developing and launching the first ever 
National Financial Inclusion Strategy for Women, which sets out clear targets and actions for 
narrowing gaps in entrepreneurship, digital finance, insurance and pensions, financial literacy and 
education, consumer protection, data collection, and support for women caregivers; (ii) adopting 
a national definition of businesses owned or led by women as a first step toward developing more 
gender-focused policy support in subprogram 2; (iii) establishing a national women’s financial 
inclusion network to promote inter-ministerial cooperation and collaboration with development 
partners; (iv) focusing especially on women’s businesses in the EIFIL; and (v) including the 
Ministry of Women’s Empowerment to support the National Strategy for Financial Inclusion, 2020–
2024. Subprogram 2 will build on these actions by supporting women’s businesses in the fintech 
industry, promoting access to markets through gender-responsive procurement guidelines, and 
conducting pilots and new research on women’s unpaid caregiving. 
 
24.  Governance. Indonesia has demonstrated sound macroeconomic management. From 
2015 to 2019, before the COVID-19 pandemic, economic expansion averaged 5.0%, inflation was 
carefully managed, and the fiscal deficit equaled on average 2.3% of gross domestic product. 
Indonesia  has  effectively  coped  with  past  external  shocks  through  sound  macroeconomic 
management.25 Coordinated macroeconomic management by the Ministry of Finance, Bank 
Indonesia,  and  the  OJK  remains  strong  in  response  to  external  uncertainties.  In  addition, 
assessment of Indonesia’s public expenditure and financial accountability confirms that the 
government  has  established  a  strong  legal  and  regulatory  framework  aligned  with  most 
international  standards  on  good  governance.  International  standards  on  public  financial 
management have been adopted for accounting, budget classification, and internal control and 
audit.26 A 2017 government regulation mandates coordination between the National Development

25.  Risk  and  mitigating  measures.  Two  key  risks  have  been  identified. 27  First, 
macroeconomic instability and a prolonged COVID-19 pandemic may change political priorities, 
leaving  the  government  with  fewer  resources  to  implement  financial  inclusion  reform. 
Macroeconomic instability is mitigated by Indonesia’s sound macroeconomic fundamentals and 
appropriate monetary and fiscal policies. The government has acted to mitigate the impact of 
COVID-19 by temporarily lifting the fiscal deficit ceiling of 3% of gross domestic product and by 
providing additional support to the health-care sector, social protection, and economic assistance, 
especially for the poor and vulnerable. ADB is also supporting the government’s fiscal policy 
response to the pandemic through a countercyclical support loan, TA, and conducting regular 
policy dialogue. Second, there is potential risk from the emerging fintech industry and its possible 
disruption of safety, security, and stability in the finance sector. The OJK remains responsible for 
developing and supervising the fintech industry, including through a regulatory sandbox. Reform 
under the program will address other risks to financial exclusion and fintech industry supervision. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
 
26.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the program shall conform to 
all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the loan 
agreement. 
 
27.  In addition to the standard assurances, the government has agreed to the following 
condition: the effectiveness of the loan is conditional upon the government’s issuance of a 
Presidential Regulation on its National Financial Inclusion Strategy.
